content: I've seen threads about what was the best assignment and what the best duty, was but just to see something new and exciting made it the right place for me. I spent less than two years at Holloman AFB (.MIL website) but I saw more things that just put me back in my seat, with jaw slack in total wonder. One of my absolute favorite places to be was at the "Rocket Test Sled Track" there at Holloman. To see a rocket take off sideways and blast down the railway at top speed to perform one test or another. Truely fascinating speed and power you feel deep into your bones. A rocket is an amazing thing to watch when ignited. What was your favorite place? Not just a Duty Station but a favorite place on a base, on a ship, or on overnight bivouac. Quantum materiae materietur marmota monax si marmota monax materiam possit materiari?

title: My Favorite Duty Station, Work Area.

content: Munich,Germany I was stationed there for a few years. 200 Military and most of us wore civilian cloths and it was more of a family than a duty station. Just look it up and see why I loved so much. And my son was born there. MD
reply: Munich,Germany I was stationed there for a few years. 200 Military and most of us wore civilian cloths and it was more of a family than a duty station. Just look it up and see why I loved so much. And my son was born there. MD
title: My Favorite Duty Station, Work Area.

content: 2 Separate tours plus Just Cause at Howard AFB Panama. Fishing, camping, hiking, GIRLS, food, beaches, diving, island hopping and space-a cruises through the canal on luxury liners for less than 20 bucks one way just to name a few of the things I did EVERY weekend ... or whatever my days off I had that week. Don't really remember if I worked there or not. Had the time of my life there though! I may have gotten drunk a time or two ... or three
reply: 2 Separate tours plus Just Cause at Howard AFB Panama. Fishing, camping, hiking, GIRLS, food, beaches, diving, island hopping and space-a cruises through the canal on luxury liners for less than 20 bucks one way just to name a few of the things I did EVERY weekend ... or whatever my days off I had that week. Don't really remember if I worked there or not. Had the time of my life there though! I may have gotten drunk a time or two ... or three
title: My Favorite Duty Station, Work Area.

content: How about the best place and the worse place and they are the same place? I would say, for me, it had to my assignment to the United States Army Finance and Accounting Office, Europe. The good points: It was a concurrent/accompanies dependences; we arrived in October 1963 and rotated back to the USA in November 1967. I was promoted to E6 and E7 during that time. We wore civilian clothes and had a reserved parking space in the building. Great places to see and to visit. A good commissary and exchange system. Waiting list for quarters was 24 months. Waiting list for a phone was four years. Single guys loved it. The bad points: The city was dirty, the locals didn’t like American. Commuting time from affordable “local housing” was 45 minutes to two hours. From government quarters it was and hour and 15 minutes to three hours. Most family guys were not happy with it. The commissary and exchange was 10-12 miles form most housing. Oh yes, the location, downtown Paris France, 32 Rue Mar Buff. OAL God and the soldier, All men adore, In time of trouble, And no more; For when war is over, And all things righted, God is neglected - The old soldier slighted. Founding Member Original DVG & Proud Member, Rupterd Duck/Derelict Veterans

OAL God and the soldier, All men adore, In time of trouble, And no more; For when war is over, And all things righted, God is neglected - The old soldier slighted. Founding Member Original DVG & Proud Member, Rupterd Duck/Derelict Veterans

title: My Favorite Duty Station, Work Area.

content: 1. NAS Miramar, San Diego Ca. 2. NAS Pt. Mugu, Ca. Pt. Mugu was NAS backyard. I grew up in Thousand Oaks which is about 20 miles away. Thousand Oaks High School, class of '70. NAS Miramar, AKA Fighter Town is in San Diego Ca. Great weather and beaches. Did two tours first with VC-13 and second with VFC-13. Yeah, it's the same squadron. Best of all, that's where I met my wife. We were married in 1983. Still together.
reply: 1. NAS Miramar, San Diego Ca. 2. NAS Pt. Mugu, Ca. Pt. Mugu was NAS backyard. I grew up in Thousand Oaks which is about 20 miles away. Thousand Oaks High School, class of '70. content: Naval Communications Station, Rota Spain, Facilities Control Operator 1974-77

title: My Favorite Duty Station, Work Area.

content: Atlantic Undersea Test and Evaluation Center (A.U.T.E.C.), Naval Underwater Systems Center, Naval Base, Andros Island, Bahamas October 1975 to February 1977 Base Fire Department Nice Quarters, Excellent Chow, Good People. The downside of it was the base was in a well-known Hurricane Region...and "The Triangle". All supplies were either flown in to the small "International Airport" near Andros Town, shipped in via a old WW2 LST under Panamanian Flag, or the LSU that was part of the 'fleet'...consisting of 12 105' TWRs (Torpedo Weapons Retreivers), the LSU, and the sister ship of the USS Pueblo. And those damn land crabs!
reply: Atlantic Undersea Test and Evaluation Center (A.U.T.E.C.), Naval Underwater Systems Center, Naval Base, Andros Island, Bahamas October 1975 to February 1977 Base Fire Department Nice Quarters, Excellent Chow, Good People. And those damn land crabs!

title: My Favorite Duty Station, Work Area.

content: In my 20 years in the Army I honestly never had a bad duty station. I did enjoy being overseas much more than CONUS. I served 6 years in Korea, 5 years in Germany and 1 year in RVN, plus a month in Panama (JWTC). My 2 most memorable assignments were with the Defense Attache Office in Seoul, Korea, and a 3 year classified assignment in Germany as an interrogator.
reply: In my 20 years in the Army I honestly never had a bad duty station. I did enjoy being overseas much more than CONUS. I served 6 years in Korea, 5 years in Germany and 1 year in RVN, plus a month in Panama (JWTC). title: My Favorite Duty Station, Work Area.

content: My last 3 of my 6 yrs in the USCG, Station Islamorada, FL Keys, followed by 12 more years at the US Customs Office right down the same canal. The reason; whenever I left the dock, I had the fealing chances were good we'd have some excitement that day/night since Cuba was only about 130 miles away and the Bahamas, maybe 40 miles away. Sure, there were many boring shifts but it was all the exciting ones that made it a great place to work. All the babes in bikinis didn't hurt either. Don

A rocket is an amazing thing to watch when ignited. What was your favorite place? Not just a Duty Station but a favorite place on a base, on a ship, or on overnight bivouac. Quantum materiae materietur marmota monax si marmota monax materiam possit materiari?
reply: I've seen threads about what was the best assignment and what the best duty, was but just to see something new and exciting made it the right place for me. I spent less than two years at Holloman AFB (.MIL website) but I saw more things that just put me back in my seat, with jaw slack in total wonder. content: Munich,Germany I was stationed there for a few years. 200 Military and most of us wore civilian cloths and it was more of a family than a duty station. Just look it up and see why I loved so much. And my son was born there. MD

title: My Favorite Duty Station, Work Area.

content: 2 Separate tours plus Just Cause at Howard AFB Panama. Fishing, camping, hiking, GIRLS, food, beaches, diving, island hopping and space-a cruises through the canal on luxury liners for less than 20 bucks one way just to name a few of the things I did EVERY weekend ... or whatever my days off I had that week. Don't really remember if I worked there or not. Had the time of my life there though! I may have gotten drunk a time or two ... or three

title: My Favorite Duty Station, Work Area.

content: How about the best place and the worse place and they are the same place? I would say, for me, it had to my assignment to the United States Army Finance and Accounting Office, Europe. The good points: It was a concurrent/accompanies dependences; we arrived in October 1963 and rotated back to the USA in November 1967. I was promoted to E6 and E7 during that time. We wore civilian clothes and had a reserved parking space in the building. Great places to see and to visit. A good commissary and exchange system. Waiting list for quarters was 24 months. Waiting list for a phone was four years. Single guys loved it. The bad points: The city was dirty, the locals didn’t like American. Commuting time from affordable “local housing” was 45 minutes to two hours. From government quarters it was and hour and 15 minutes to three hours. Most family guys were not happy with it. The commissary and exchange was 10-12 miles form most housing. Oh yes, the location, downtown Paris France, 32 Rue Mar Buff. OAL God and the soldier, All men adore, In time of trouble, And no more; For when war is over, And all things righted, God is neglected - The old soldier slighted. Founding Member Original DVG & Proud Member, Rupterd Duck/Derelict Veterans

content: 1. NAS Miramar, San Diego Ca. 2. NAS Pt. Mugu, Ca. Pt. Mugu was NAS backyard. I grew up in Thousand Oaks which is about 20 miles away. Thousand Oaks High School, class of '70. NAS Miramar, AKA Fighter Town is in San Diego Ca. Great weather and beaches. Did two tours first with VC-13 and second with VFC-13. Yeah, it's the same squadron. Best of all, that's where I met my wife. We were married in 1983. Still together.

title: My Favorite Duty Station, Work Area.

content: Atlantic Undersea Test and Evaluation Center (A.U.T.E.C.), Naval Underwater Systems Center, Naval Base, Andros Island, Bahamas October 1975 to February 1977 Base Fire Department Nice Quarters, Excellent Chow, Good People. The downside of it was the base was in a well-known Hurricane Region...and "The Triangle". All supplies were either flown in to the small "International Airport" near Andros Town, shipped in via a old WW2 LST under Panamanian Flag, or the LSU that was part of the 'fleet'...consisting of 12 105' TWRs (Torpedo Weapons Retreivers), the LSU, and the sister ship of the USS Pueblo. And those damn land crabs!

content: In my 20 years in the Army I honestly never had a bad duty station. I did enjoy being overseas much more than CONUS. I served 6 years in Korea, 5 years in Germany and 1 year in RVN, plus a month in Panama (JWTC). My 2 most memorable assignments were with the Defense Attache Office in Seoul, Korea, and a 3 year classified assignment in Germany as an interrogator.
reply: In my 20 years in the Army I honestly never had a bad duty station. I did enjoy being overseas much more than CONUS. content: My last 3 of my 6 yrs in the USCG, Station Islamorada, FL Keys, followed by 12 more years at the US Customs Office right down the same canal. The reason; whenever I left the dock, I had the fealing chances were good we'd have some excitement that day/night since Cuba was only about 130 miles away and the Bahamas, maybe 40 miles away. Sure, there were many boring shifts but it was all the exciting ones that made it a great place to work. All the babes in bikinis didn't hurt either. Don
